title: Regional Revitalization JP-Meetup
description: Deindustrialization (high aging, depopulation, shortage of engineers in local areas) is serious problem for developed country Japan

f6_assessments.q0: A Japanese community hub is a great idea to promote this blockchain in Japan, a market that only recently opened up full access to ADA. Combining that with launching a token that can eventually provide revenue so the hub funds itsself is also a great idea as it will create a form of independency and economic stimulant. Great name for the token, by the way. It fits the sentiment for this proposal.
f6_assessments.q1:
This project has already an amount of participants over 100 strong, performing sessions on an irregular basis. The proposers hold contact with Toshiaki Miyatake, which is the Japan Campaign Manager for IOG. 
As I understood from the proposal, there is Yoshino-gawa city personnel involved in the organisation of this hub in combination with as much as 3 unknown youth business groups. 
3K USD to kickstart this doesn't sound like a lot. Are you sure this is enough?
f6_assessments.q2: The slides and website link help a lot with determining the intent of the proposal. There is also a roadmap and rudimentary funding breakdown in place. There is even a location already selected where the meetups would take place to host this hub. It was not really clear if the hub would want to expand to other cities as well later on. As the city it wants to operate in has a limited amount of residents numbering 42132 people. This could use clarification in the proposal. In addition, proposing this partly in Japanese creates a language barrier for many CAs and voters. Thus limiting feedback and amount of people this can reach in the general Cardano community. I had to use a translator myself, resulting in this quotation for auditability. Consider completely translating it in English, as it's the current lingua franca of the world, to reach a maximal amount of people and greatly improving the auditability of this proposal.

f6_assessments.q0: Holding seminars to educate people about Cardano is great. Finding ways to benefit the community using Cardano should be an essential part of these seminars. Holding a seminar each month for 3 months in a row can help with creating awareness.
f6_assessments.q1:
Already committed team on board. Not much info or  evidence regarding the teams experience is provided. You could ad links to profile pages or just provide any info that will create more voter trust.
The budget allocation and plan seems very sensible.
The timeline to execute this should be fine.
f6_assessments.q2: They provided a roadmap with milestones. They will publish reports from their meetups, making the tracking of progress and success easier. More details should be given on how the original Hotaru token will be used before, during and after the final event. I believe the plan will be refined with each successful seminar coming from this proposal's funding.

f6_assessments.q0: The problem and the solution to the problem are not presented in a clear and understandable manner for any outsider. The proposer should identify a specific  problem of the community (The depopulation, as a problem, could be solved with the help of the blockchain technology?) and provide a meaningful solution to address and to solve the problem (if possible). If the proposer wants to establish a hub in the targeted community then the solution needs to be rephrased and has to show how it will add value to the Cardano ecosystem and how the community will benefit from this partnership.
f6_assessments.q1:
The proposer, based on the translation of the info provided, has some experience skills for the proposal to be implemented. The proposer should draw a team (if necessary) and assign roles to each team member. The proposer should add reference (links, any other accessible resources) about the experience/skills for each team member.
The budget should be broken down into identifiable items (any expenses regarding the resources to be used - salary, stationary, office rent etc.). The proposal should provide a sensible and conductible plan for implementation that shows not only what is being done but also how. (how the info will be presented to the audience (video, papers etc.)?)

If additional funding is required to implement the proposal, the proposer should provide a verifiable plan in this regard. (resource needed and a budget to achieve the desired goals)
f6_assessments.q2: Roadmap and milestones (incl. time horizon) are weakly described. It is only mentioned that further funding will be needed. As mentioned above, the description of the solution is inadequate and confusing. Possible challenges are not considered. In conclusion, the progress of this proposal is hard to assess.

f6_assessments.q0: Since Cardano has been getting more notice in Japan this is a great initiative to promote Cardano in japan. The creation of a community center would greatly benefit the publicity in Japan. Even having future plans to create a token for supporting the hub shows the proposer intends to push this project further. This proposal fits the challenge settings.
f6_assessments.q1: If I can trust the translation of Google this proposal already has 100 active participants how sporadically have meetings. The plan provided is split into 3 parts but this proposal only affects the first step. The first step is securing a larger community by planning seminars the help the understanding is a perfect first step. Seeing that you keep in touch with Toshiaki Miyatake, the Japanese Campaign Manager at IOHK gives great confidence. The only concern I have is the amount you asked for, will it be enough for holding 3 seminars?
f6_assessments.q2: For auditability, I had my concerns since you started the proposal by writing in English. I know it's hard to express yourself in a language that is not your native language but in Catalyst we have an unspoken rule to speak en propose in English. This way most people can understand the proposals to a certain degree. We even have helpers who help translate English to their native language. That being said the rest of the proposal provides solid evidence for further assessment. The slides give extra info on the proposal to help following the proposal.

f6_assessments.q0: It is a bit difficult to comprehend this proposal. It sounds like some seminars on Cardano are supposed to be given, but the content is not really explained. Why another token is introduced is not explained either.
f6_assessments.q1: It is likely the team is capable of giving some input in Cardano to local people. Whether they will be able to program a native token remeims unclear because they don't explain a lot about their qualifications.
f6_assessments.q2: Since the format is pretty open it will be difficult to Audit anything other than the creation of the token and the question whether the meetings actually took place.

f6_assessments.q0: While the problem statement indeed is an issue for Japan, it is not clear how this issue relates to the scaling up of the Cardano community in Japan. The problem solution was only submitted in Japanese, translated it reads: 'We ask people who are currently active in the Japanese community and IOGs to hold study sessions to improve blockchain knowledge and train engineers, and create a blockchain promotion activity community in rural areas on the Web. Create a place to raise problems for meeting up and solving problems.' The proposal would benefit from a more detailed listing of key metrics and goals as only general metrics and goals are given. The proposal has a strong plan for scaling to address future challenges.
f6_assessments.q1: The proposal relevant experience section is only given in Japanese, translated it reads: 'Since four years ago, we have been holding blockchain and crypto asset dissemination activities and study sessions on an irregular basis. My community is over 100 people locally. I kept in touch with IOG Toshiaki Miyatake and shared information and knowledge about Cardano and disseminated it in the community.' The team members are only generally described, more information regarding their experience and connections with the Yoshino-gawa city area would be useful. The budget is reasonable but is only stated in general terms of $1k per seminar for 3 seminars offered over a three month timeframe. Development of the seminar materials and the resources needed to hold the seminar are not delineated. Additionally, if the goal is to train new engineers more direction might be given to the readers as to the audience target (HS students, University students, ...). Mention of how the seminars might be captured (recorded) and disseminated (YouTube and/or Nico Nico Douga ( ニコニコ動画)) so as to capture and further grow the community beyond those who were able to attend the seminar.
f6_assessments.q2: The plan offers general milestones of the three seminars but would benefit from more details for the STEP1 section of the plan as that is the part that will determine if they are to receive funding. The description of the problem and the proposed solution both in the body of the proposal and in the Problem-Solution fields at the top would benefit from increased alignment.

f6_assessments.q0: Solid presentation that details a valid problem and suggests a viable solution. There are some language barriers for my assessment but with the assistance of google translator I was happy to present 5 star rating. The proposal is a grass roots venture that seeks to educate a local Japanese province of Cardano values and conduct engineering hubs. The team appear to have already started on this journey and present some localised ideas that may well promote adoption and help add value to the Cardano   ecosystem.
f6_assessments.q1: The experience of the team was not easy to review but appears sufficient to drive the proposal and may well be understated in the content that accompanied the proposal. The plan presented for this fund is preliminary in nature and the budget reflects this point. Of great interest are the future plans that the team intends to pursue in future funds and I like this approach as it allows for the Catalyst community to evaluate the team and their work without a large budget outlay and hence building trust for future funding rounds. I would encourage the team to share  more of themselves in the ideascale text as some voters may not delve deeper to ascertain their skills and project design.
f6_assessments.q2: I found the information provided was sufficient to audit and that the links helped to see what is a very promising proposal. Language was a minor issue but in reality it should not count against the team. The metrics/KPI's are not lofty and as such are attainable. I think the requested funds are very reasonable and hope that the team explores ways to summarise the meaningful content for future fund proposals. I am confident that this proposal has the hallmarks of success and wish the team strength for the future.

solution: ブロックチェーンの知識向上、技術者の育成などに現在日本コミュニティで活動している方やIOGの方たちに講師を依頼して勉強会の開催、また地方でのブロックチェーン普及活動コミュニティを作りWebでのミートアップや課題解決に向けた問題提起の場所作りをする。
experience:
4年前からブロックチェーンそして暗号資産の普及活動、勉強会を不定期に開催してきました。

自分のコミュニティは地元で100人を超えています。

IOG宮武 俊明さんと連絡を取り合いカルダノに関する情報や知識を共有していただきコミュニティで発信していました。
